question.title: Ninja Competition
question.content:
Our hero Ninja is organizing a coding competition where only two teams can participate simultaneously. To make the competition interesting and fair, both the teams should have an equal number of members. As an organizer, Ninja got the task of making the two teams.

There are some conditions for creating teams. For each competition, he will be given a number ‘N’, and for each divisor ‘D’ of ‘N’ ( including 1 and ‘N’ itself ), he will add a member:

1) to the first team if ‘D’ is even.

2) to the second team if ‘D’ is odd.

Since Ninja is very busy organizing the event, he wants you to help him with the task. Your task is to tell Ninja if he can create two teams with an equal number of members.

For Example:
For ‘N’ = 10,
The divisors are:
1, 2, 5, 10.
The first team will have two members corresponding to divisors 2 and 10.
The second team will have two members corresponding to divisors 1 and 5.
So, in this case, Ninja can make two teams.
Input Format:
The first line contains an integer ‘T’ which denotes the number of test cases to run.

Then the test case follows:

The first and only line of each test case contains an integer ‘N’ denoting the number given to Ninja.
Output Format:
For each test case print ‘true’ if Ninja can make two teams of equal members with the given ‘N’, else print ‘false’.

Output for each test case will be printed in a separate line.
Note:
You are not required to print anything, it has already been taken care of. Just implement the function.
Constraints:
1 <= T <= 100
1 <= N <= 10^5

It is guaranteed that the sum of N over all test cases doesn’t exceed 10^5.

Time Limit: 1 sec
Sample Input 1:
2
7
14
Sample Output 1:
false
true
Explanation For Sample Output 1:
In test case 1:

N = 7, the divisors of 7 are 1,7.
The first team will have 0 members since there are no even divisors.
The second team will have 2 members corresponding to divisors 1 and 7.
Since the teams have a different number of members, the output will be false.

In test case 2:

N=14, the divisors of 14 are 1,2,7,14.
The first team will have 2 members corresponding to divisors 2 and 14.
The second team will have 2 members corresponding to divisors 1 and 7.
Since the teams have the same number of members, the output will be true.
Sample Input 2:
2
2
20
Sample Output 2:
true
false

rephrased.body: Ninja is organizing a coding competition where two teams compete simultaneously. To ensure fairness, both teams must have an equal number of members. Given an integer N, Ninja assigns members to teams based on its divisors. For each divisor D of N (including 1 and N): a member is added to the first team if D is even and to the second team if D is odd. Determine if Ninja can create two teams with an equal number of members.
constraints: The sum of N over all test cases doesn’t exceed 10^5

testcases.explanation:
For N = 7, the divisors are 1 and 7. The first team has 0 members (no even divisors), and the second team has 2 members (1 and 7).  Since the team sizes are unequal, the output is false.

For N = 14, the divisors are 1, 2, 7, and 14. The first team has 2 members (2 and 14), and the second team has 2 members (1 and 7). Since the team sizes are equal, the output is true.

For N = 2, the divisors are 1 and 2. The first team has 1 member (2), and the second team has 1 member (1).  Since the team sizes are equal, the output is true.

For N = 20, the divisors are 1, 2, 4, 5, 10, 20. The first team has 4 members (2, 4, 10, 20), and the second team has 2 members (1, 5).  Since the team sizes are unequal, the output is false.

hints: Find all the divisors of ‘N’ and count the number of odd and even divisors.
Can you find all the divisors in sqrt(‘N’)?
All the numbers with equal counts of odd and even integers form an Arithmetic Progression.
